Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 11:29AM Shar1 wrote: Breast density is a major factor in the failure of mammography to detect breast cancer.  Many states are now requiring that women be informed of their breast density along with their mammogram results.  I am 42, pre-menopausal and have dense breasts.   Just this summer I had an inconclusive mammogram along with a bi-lateral compression test and an ultrasound that were all unable to confirm the absence of cancer because of my density.  I ended up having a BSGI/MBI(Molecular Breast Imaging) test which is good for women with dense tissue.  I received an injection of a tracer accumulates in the cancer cells and makes them light up on the computer screen.  This test is said to be comparable to an MRI and was extremely easy.  I would definitely recommend it to anyone who is not comfortable with the results of their mammogram or ultrasound and wants to ease their mind.
Posts.Title: Dense Breast Tissue Reminder Aug242007 Shar1

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 10:21AM - edited Sep 12, 2012 10:21AM by Shar1 I did not have the MRI but I would think that BSGI/MBI is less traumatic---the procedure took only about 30 minutes and was similar to a mammogram except I was sitting down.   Insurance does cover it and I think it is cheaper than the MRI.  I am pretty sure it is not a "screening test" but more of a diagnostice test.  It is primarily used if the mammogram is inconclusive.   I actually had the opportunity to meet a lady that had a lump that she could feel to the touch but yet it did not show up on her mammogram because of density.  She said that her doctor pushed for her to have the BSGI and it found a cancer.   Bottom line is that you have to be your own advocate.  Mammograms will continue to be the "first" test for me but if I'm not comfortable with the results of my mammogram next year I will push for MBI again.  Insurance companies are difficult to deal with but don't allow them to dictate your breast health!
Posts.Title: Dense Breast Tissue Reminder Aug242007 Shar1

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2012 07:06AM Shar1 wrote: This is good news, I am sooooo glad that they do not think that it is anything to be worried about.  I went to the breast center yesterday and they scheduled my BSGI molecular breast imaging test for next Thursday and I am ready for a little peace of mind.  I will let you know how it goes because studies show that it is really good for women with dense tissue and it could be helpful for you.  Hugs!
Posts.Title: palpable mass - negative mammogram bkala SpecialK

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2012 09:32AM Shar1 wrote: You may want to ask about BSGI/MBI when you go tomorrow.  I recently had a suspicious mammogram and was called back in for a lateral spot compression which did not answer any questions so I was sent for an ultrasound immediately.  The radiologist came in and did the ultrasound himself and said that I have a dense area close to my chest wall and ribs.  He said that there was a change in my mammogram over the past year and that this dense area is not normal.  They are sending me for the BSGI test---I got my doctors order yesterday and will probably go next week.  Anyway, I have been told that BSGI is comprable to MRI and is very good for high-risk women, especially women with dense breasts.  It detects the presence of cancer immediately and is used when the mammograms are inconsulsive and in my case so was the ultrasound.  Best of luck to you tomorrow!
Posts.Title: palpable mass - negative mammogram bkala SpecialK

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2012 03:15PM Shar1 wrote: Just this summer I had an inconclusive mammogram along with a bi-lateral compression test and an ultrasound that were all unable to confirm the absence of cancer because of my density.  I ended up having a BSGI/MBI test which is 98% accurate in determining if there is cancer or not.  I received an injection of a tracer that accumulates in the cancer cells and makes them light up on the computer screen.  This test can eliminate an unnecessary biopsy and keep you from waiting----don't wait--a lot can happen in 6 months! I would definitely recommend MBI to anyone who is not comfortable with the results of their mammogram or ultrasound and wants to ease their mind.
Posts.Title: 1st ultrasound found mass, repeat ultrasound found nothing lola12 Shar1

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2012 03:05PM Shar1 wrote: I am sorry that you have so much going on-- I recently had suspicious mammograms, ultrasounds and one doctor recommended that I have a biopsy.  I ended up having a test called MBI-Molecular Breast Imaging--- I received an injection of a tracer that accumulates in the cancer cells and makes them light up and can eliminate an unnecessary biopsy.  Definately ask about it---- it is said to be 98% accurate in determining if there is cancer present and it was very easy--similar to a mammogram except I was sitting down.  I was relieved to find out that there was no cancer in my breasts without having a biopsy.  Good Luck
